pyttn.oqs.bath_hamiltonian module

pyttn.oqs.bosonic_bath module

class pyttn.oqs.bosonic_bath.BosonicBath(Jw, S=None, beta=None, wmax=inf, wmin=None)[source]

Bases: object

A class for managing a continuous bosonic gaussian bath. This provides functions for computing non-interacting bath correlation functions, as well as decomposing the correlation function into a linear combination of complex valued exponentials (expfit) or oscillator terms (discretise) :param Jw: The bath spectral function defining the non-interacting correlation function :param S: The system operator :type S: SOP, optional :param beta: The inverse temperature of the bath, defaults to None :type beta: float, optional :param wmax: the maximum frequency bound, defaults to np.inf :type wmax: float, optional :param wmin: the minimum frequency bound, defaults to None :type wmin: float, optional

Ct(t, epsabs=1.49e-12, epsrel=1.49e-12, limit=2000, epsomega=1e-06)[source]

Returns the value of the non-interacting bath correlation function evaluated at the time points t, defined by:

\[C(t) = \frac{1}{\pi}\int_{\omega_{\mathrm{min}}}^{\omega_{\mathrm{max}}} J(\omega) f_B(\beta\omega) \exp(- i \omega t)\]
Parameters:

t (np.ndarray) – time

Returns:

The bath correlation function

Return type:

np.ndarray

Ctexp(dk, zk)[source]

Returns the value of the non-interacting bath correlation function evaluated at the time points t using the results of discretisation or expfit: :param t: time :type t: np.ndarray :param dk: the weights of each term in the fit :type dk: np.ndarray :param zk: the (complex) frequencies of each term in the fit :type zk: np.ndarray :return: The bath correlation function :rtype: np.ndarray

Sw(w)[source]

Returns the non-interacting bath spectral function at w :param w: frequency :type w: np.ndarray :param Ef: Fermi Energy :type Ef: float :param sigma: Whether to compute the spectral function associated with the greater (+) or lesser (-) Green’s Function, default to + :type sigma: str, optional :return: The bath correlation function :rtype: np.ndarray

discretise(discretisation_engine)[source]

Returns the coupling constants and frequencies associated with a discretised representation of the bath :param discretisation_energy: The object used to discretise the c :type w: np.ndarray :param Ef: Fermi Energy :type Ef: float :param sigma: Whether to compute the spectral function associated with the greater (+) or lesser (-) Green’s Function, default to + :type sigma: str, optional :return: The bath correlation function :rtype: np.ndarray

estimate_bounds(wmax=None)[source]

Returns estimates for the upper and lower bounds of the spectral density to be used for the discretisation function :param wmax: the maximum frequency bound, defaults to self.wmax :type wmax: float, optional :return: the maximum and minimum frequency bounds :rtype: float, float

expfit(fitting_engine)[source]
find_wmin(wmax, npoints=1000)[source]

pyttn.oqs.exponential_fit_bath module

class pyttn.oqs.exponential_fit_bath.ExpFitBosonicBath(dk, zk, combine_real=False, tol=1e-12)[source]

Bases: ExpFitOQSBath

A class for handling a bosonic bath representing an exponential fit to a bath correlation function of the form

\[C(t) = \sum_k d_{k} \exp(-z_k t)\]
Parameters:

  • dk (np.ndarray) – The coefficient in the exponential decomposition

  • zk (np.ndarray) – The decay rates in the exponential decomposition

  • combine_real (bool, optional) – Whether or not to combine real frequency modes (default False)

  • tol (float, optional) – The tolerance used to determine if a mode is a real frequency mode (default 1e-12)

Ct(t)[source]

Returns the value of the non-interacting bath correlation function evaluated at the time points t, defined by:

\[C(t) = \sum_k d_{k} \exp(-z_k t)\]
Parameters:

t (np.ndarray) – time

Returns:

The bath correlation function

Return type:

np.ndarray

system_information()[source]

Constructs and returns a system_modes object suitable for handling the bath degrees of freedom described by this object.

Returns:

Bath system information

Return type:

system_modes

truncate_modes(truncation=<pyttn.utils.truncate.DepthTruncation object>)[source]

Determines the local Hilbert space dimension (stored in mode_dims) of each of the bosonic bath modes using the truncation rule defined in the truncation object.

Parameters:

truncation – The truncation rule used to determine the potentially frequency and coupling strength dependent

local Hilbert space dimension for each mode in the bath. (Default DepthTruncation(8)) :type truncation: TruncationBase, optional

class pyttn.oqs.exponential_fit_bath.ExpFitFermionicBath(dk, zk, combine_real=False, tol=1e-12)[source]

Bases: ExpFitOQSBath

A class for handling a fermionic bath representing an exponential fit to a bath correlation function of the form

\[C(t) = \sum_k d_{k} \exp(-z_k t)\]
Parameters:

  • dk (np.ndarray) – The coefficient in the exponential decomposition

  • zk (np.ndarray) – The decay rates in the exponential decomposition

  • combine_real (bool, optional) – Whether or not to combine real frequency modes (default False)

  • tol (float, optional) – The tolerance used to determine if a mode is a real frequency mode (default 1e-12)

truncate_modes(truncation=<pyttn.utils.truncate.DepthTruncation object>)[source]

Determines the local Hilbert space dimension (stored in mode_dims) of each of the bosonic bath modes using the truncation rule defined in the truncation object.

Parameters:

truncation – The truncation rule used to determine the potentially frequency and coupling strength dependent

local Hilbert space dimension for each mode in the bath. (Default DepthTruncation(2)) :type truncation: TruncationBase, optional

class pyttn.oqs.exponential_fit_bath.ExpFitOQSBath(dk, zk, fermionic=False, combine_real=False, tol=1e-12)[source]

Bases: object

The base class for handling a bath representing an exponential fit to a bath correlation function of the form

\[C(t) = \sum_k d_{k} \exp(-z_k t)\]
Parameters:

  • dk (np.ndarray) – The coefficient in the exponential decomposition

  • zk (np.ndarray) – The decay rates in the exponential decomposition

  • fermionic (bool, optional) – Whether or not the bath is a fermionic bath (default False)

  • combine_real (bool, optional) – Whether or not to combine real frequency modes (default False)

  • tol (float, optional) – The tolerance used to determine if a mode is a real frequency mode (default 1e-12)

property dk

An array containing the bath decomposition coefficients

is_fermionic()[source]

Returns whether or not the bath is fermionic :rtype: bool

property mode_dims

An array containing the dimensionality of each of the modes

property zk

An array containing the bath decomposition decay rates

pyttn.oqs.fermionic_bath module

class pyttn.oqs.fermionic_bath.FermionicBath(Jw, Sp=None, Sm=None, beta=None, wmax=inf, wmin=None, wtol=None)[source]

Bases: object

A class for managing a continuous fermionic gaussian bath. This provides functions for computing non-interacting bath correlation functions, as well as decomposing the correlation function into a linear combination of complex valued exponentials (expfit) or oscillator terms (discretise) :param Jw: The bath spectral function defining the non-interacting correlation function :param beta: The inverse temperature of the bath, defaults to None :type beta: float, optional :param wmax: the maximum frequency bound, default to np.inf :type wmax: float, optional :param wmin: the minimum frequency bound, default to np.inf :type wmin: float, optional :param wtol: a value for determining wmin based on wmax. See fermionic.bath.estimate_bounds, default to None :type wtol: float, optional

Ct(t, Ef=0, sigma='+', epsabs=1.49e-12, epsrel=1.49e-12, limit=2000)[source]

Returns the value of the non-interacting bath correlation function evaluated at the time points t:

\[C^{\sigma}(t) = \frac{1}{pi}\int_{wmin}^{wmax} J(\omega) f_F(\sigma\beta(\omega - Ef)) exp(\sigma i \omega t)\]
Parameters:

  • t (np.ndarray) – time

  • Ef (float, optional) – The fermi energy, default to 0

  • sigma (str, optional) – Whether to compute greater (+) or lesser (-) Green’s Function, default to +

Returns:

The bath correlation function

Return type:

np.ndarray

Ctexp(dk, zk, sigma='+')[source]

Returns the value of the non-interacting bath correlation function evaluated at the time points t using the results of discretisation or expfit: :param t: time :type t: np.ndarray :param dk: the weights of each term in the fit :type dk: np.ndarray :param zk: the (complex) frequencies of each term in the fit :type zk: np.ndarray :param sigma: Whether to compute greater (+) or lesser (-) Green’s Function, default to + :type sigma: str, optional :return: The bath correlation function :rtype: np.ndarray

Sw(w, Ef=0, sigma='+')[source]

Returns the non-interacting bath spectral function at w and fermi energy Ef :param w: frequency :type w: np.ndarray :param Ef: Fermi Energy :type Ef: float :param sigma: Whether to compute the spectral function associated with the greater (+) or lesser (-) Green’s Function, default to + :type sigma: str, optional :return: The bath correlation function :rtype: np.ndarray

discretise(discretisation_engine, Ef=0, sigma='+')[source]
estimate_bounds(wmax=None, Ef=0, sigma='+')[source]

Returns estimates for the upper and lower bounds of the spectral density to be used for the discretisation function :param wmax: the maximum frequency bound, defaults to self.wmax :type wmax: float, optional :param Ef: Fermi Energy :type Ef: float :param sigma: Whether to compute the spectral function associated with the greater (+) or lesser (-) Green’s Function, default to + :type sigma: str, optional :return: the maximum and minimum frequency bounds :rtype: float, float

expfit(fitting_engine, Ef=0, sigma='+')[source]
fermi_distrib(w, Ef)[source]

Returns the value fermi function at w and fermi energy Ef: :param w: frequency :type w: np.ndarray :param Ef: Fermi Energy :type Ef: float :return: The bath correlation function :rtype: np.ndarray
